title: Need pairing suggestion
content:
Background: I created the font pictured here as the basis for a logo by manipulating [Samarkan](http://web.archive.org/web/20080706110402/http:/www.dafont.com/samarkan.font), mostly by removing the horizontal line across the top. The client, an event planner, wants an exotic but not specifically ethnic feel. Mehndi-inspired decoration will appear in the logo as well — again, trying not to be too specifically Indian but using similar flourishes.

Question: If you were asked to put the subtitle “custom designed events” below the company name, what secondary typefaces would you try?

Thanks for any suggestions!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080706110402im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/heading_6622.jpg)

author: lille_havfruen

comments.content:
Probably something clean, subtle, ’neutral’, sans serif. _(Maybe slightly narrow/condensed. Because of the ’logo’ itself being quite ’quirky’ itself, already.)_

Dav

As for actually ’naming’ and suggesting typefaces: ’ [Vafle](http://web.archive.org/web/20080706110402/http:/www.suitcasetype.com/index.php?lmut=en&part=fonts&font=18)’ _(Condensed)_, by Tomáš Brousil; Or the newly released ’ [Scout](http://web.archive.org/web/20080706110402/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/Scout)’ _(Condensed)_, by Cyrus Highsmith.

Dav

Thanks, Dav. I was originally thinking of something wide, in the same style as Century Gothic, so that it could span the width of the word Panache while remaining in a small point size. Do you think this would be a bad idea?
